data.title: LargeTexture on Sprite3D
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Current master branch, Linux

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I can't use a LargeTexture on a Sprite3D. It just displays a white rect.
Is there any other way of handling large textures (>1024px) in 3D i don't know of?

Edit: My problem is not disk space but the texture size limitation on mobile devices.

data.title: SamplePlayer latency - it's just bad performance.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1-stable on Xubuntu 14.10 64-bit. Project also tested on Android 4 to 6.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Delay between action on the screen (for example clicking the button) and hearing the sounds, that is played by pressing the button with something as simple as

```
func _on_TouchScreenButton_pressed():
    get_node("SamplePlayer").play("sample")
```

 is terribly long.
From my experiments it's around 285 ms.
![godot_audio_problem_3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/19830695/63299f32-9dfd-11e6-9877-c215125b26e5.jpg)

Latency like that basically prevents people (who don't know how to use low level audio AudioServer), from creating interactive audio games.

data.title: Audio import of high frequency 48KHz sample resolution 16-bit audio files results in artifacts in sounds.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1-stable on Xubuntu 14.10 64-bit. Project also tested on Android 4 to 6.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Listen to the both sounds. First one is obviously not converted correctly.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Project explaining audio problems attached - it's problem nr 2
Originaly 16-bit, 48000 Hz sample converted with Import/AudioSample menu settings:
Max Rate ON and Max Rate Hz = 48000 does not sound incorrectly. You can hear strange artefacts/ clicking. Because it's audible in higher frequency sounds, I think it's aliasing. Godot could use better quality sample rate conversion.
![godot_audio_problem_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/19830970/bcf2f5c0-9dff-11e6-9cf2-56699cf0c933.jpg)

Original samples are attached in the sample project's /Snd folder: E5-44100.wav and E5-48000.wav
Converting E5-48000 should result in sounds with artefacts.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[Audio_problems.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/560001/Audio_problems.zip)

data.title: Multiple audio streams can't play in sync using StreamPlayer.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1-stable on Xubuntu 14.10 64-bit. Project also tested on Android 4  6.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I wanted to play audio streams in sync using StreamPlayer nodes. 
I tested 4 streams starting to play all at once, induced by _on_TouchScreenButton_pressed().
All four voices should play in the same time, creating chords. 
Instead of chords, we hear out of sync arpeggios when streams play noticeably one after another instead starting all together with unnoticeable delays.
![godot_audio_problem_1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/19830995/08ef15f8-9e00-11e6-874d-65762b7f1c14.jpg)
Setting different values to StreamPlayer "Buffering Ms" does not change anything.

**Steps to reproduce:**

My testing project explaining audio problems attached - it's problem nr 1.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[Audio_problems.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/559926/Audio_problems.zip)

data.title: Game runs in Godot but crashes when built. How can I debug the problem of the built version?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
OSX 10.11.6 - Godot Stable 2.1 OS X

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I am running the latest 2.1 stable on OS X.
I am building for OSX.

When I run the built game via the finder it loads to my menu fine. Things are there, options buttons work, but when I hit PLAY and the scene goes to change to the game scene it locks up and I have to shut down the app.

I exported again with the Debugging Enabled set to True and when the problem happened again I couldn't see any debug info.

I right clicked the app file generated and chose show package contents.

I entered and looked about, there were no log files there.

I went to the folder /Users/USERNAME/Desktop/Hangman.app/Contents/MacOS/ and ran the executable there.

This brought up a terminal window and when the crash occurred the attached image is what was looping at a rapid rate.

Image: http://imgur.com/a/uaFmB

So that's SOMETHING but what do I make of it. It's not really got anything that I feel I can go on. I hope someone can make sense of that stuff :-) as I sure can't!

Anyway, hopefully that extra info can help. Not sure if it's a Godot build bug or my issue but either way I have NO idea how to resolve it.

I have installed the latest 2.1 export templates.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
http://salonswift.com/tmp/HangMan.zip

data.title: drag preview not compatible with 'current' camera
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win7; Godot v2.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The drag preview (set with set_drag_preview()) position does not take into account a viewport that is not the 'default' viewport.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open the Drag and Drop (GUI) demo project. Add a camera to the scene and make it current. The drag preview icon is positioned relative to global 0,0 and not Viewport 0,0.

(NOTE:  All 'functional' aspects of the drag_ functions appear to work just fine with a Camera. Data itself is grabbed/dropped accurately regardless of camera positon/zoom. It's just the visual preview that seems to be acting unexpectedly)

data.title: Adopt simpler strategy for big libs on Windows
data.body:
Also fixes #6844.

As explained in **methods.py** (also explains why it fixes #6844 ):

> On Windows, due to the limited command line length, when creating a static library
> from a very high number of objects SCons will invoke "ar" once per object file;
> that makes object files with same names to be overwritten so the last wins and
> the library looses symbols defined by overwritten objects.
> By enabling quick append instead of the default mode (replacing), libraries will
> got built correctly regardless the invokation strategy.
> Furthermore, since SCons will rebuild the library from scratch when an object file
> changes, no multiple versions of the same object file will be present.

data.title: Improve Android build (Clang + tidyness)
data.body:
This is something I wanted to do for a long time.

**_This must be heavily tested (different combinations of target architectures and build variants, etc.)._**   ~~Not possible on Windows until #6844 is solved. For testing on Windows, merge #6959 first.~~

~~### **_WARNING: This is not ready to be tested/merged until I fix the Mac build since I will be pushing test commits until I get it to work. I'll remove this notice as soon as that's done._**~~
- Compile source files with Clang (Google dropped support for GCC in the NDK so Clang is the only recommended compiler). Anyway, like the NDK does, the _binutils_ are those from GNU.
- Dropped `NDK_TARGET/NDK_TARGET_X86` since only one Clang version is included, thus no choice possible. Regarding _binutils_ and **gnu-libstdc++** the NDK also includes only one version (4.9), so no choice there either.
- Remove a lot of almost duplicate code and replace with more readable constructs and variables.
- Remove dead code (old commented code).
- Remove unneeded flags for `android_stl=yes`.
- Remove explicit specification of libraries that the linker will be adding anyway (**c, m, gcc**).
- Disable RTTI for non-STL-enabled builds (the general case).
- Restrict math optimizations to _release/release_debug_.
- Try to set the compile/link flags as close as possible to what the NDK does (based on r13), which includes new stuff like strong stack protection and other security measures.
- Instruct the linker to drop unused functions (hopefully this will reduce the resulting binary size and won't break things).
- Enable multithreaded linking where available.
- Enabled linker optimization (not true LTO by now; mainly string optimization).
- ~~Fix cases of bad indentation.~~ (Superseeded by the new PEP8 effort).

data.title: sprite.set_region_rect() and bleeding pixels
data.body:
Hi I'm not sure if this is intended behavior.  But I'm creating a pixel art editor in godot, one of actions I can perform is moving a layer (a sprite) by x and y, at first I was setting the position, but wanted to figure out how to crop it to the document bounds.  I started experimenting with set_region_rect(), and was able to get pretty close to the result I wanted.

The issue is that on the borders of the ImageTexture, if there is a pixel, and I shift layer using set_region_rect(), it will bleed infinitely on that border.  Here are some examples:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/46434785/normal.PNG
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/46434785/fucked.PNG

Again not sure if this is intended.  I solved the issue by just making the imagetexture a few pixels larger, and accounting for that in all my put_pixel operations, but would be nice to not have to.

data.title: Animation save file in external editor causes problems
data.body:
**Windows 10 64-bit: Godot 2.1**

**Issue description**:
I save my animations as .tres files in a folder for editing in a separate editor.  However, if I have Godot open while editing these files, it causes some weird results.  Often times the line directly above a Call Func Track will turn into a Call Func Track and have it's key frames erased.  Sometimes no changes carry over at all when saved, but most times they will immediately change.  Also, for whatever, reason, a lot of the times the 6th track will also turn into a Call Func Track and have it's key frames erased.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create an animation with about seven tracks (might happen with less); Call Func Track as last track.  Save animation as whatever.tres and open in an external editor (using Sublime Text) with Godot running.  Modify and it should make the last track a before the Call Func Track into one and erase it's key frames.

UPDATE:  Noticed this seems to happen if tracks above the one above the Call Func Track are deleted in the external editor or Godot.

data.title: IPV6 TYPE_ANY unused and unimplemented
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
`master` branch

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Currently, `IP_Address::TYPE_ANY` is unimplemented, as evidenced by experimentation (with both TCP and UDP servers) and some IRC logs:

```
[15:18:17] <fales> punto, akien, regarding ipv6 there are still a couple of things to be noted. I think: 1 - IP_TYPE_ANY does not work (tested with udp_packet_peer) 2 - IP_TYPE_ANY should be the default value for "listen".
[15:18:59] <fales> "p_address_type != IP_Address::TYPE_IPV4 && p_address_type != IP_Address::TYPE_IPV6" drivers/unix/packet_peer_udp_posix.cpp:124
```

Opening this since I lost an hour or so on #6933 without having this in mind... :laughing: 

Pinging @Faless and @punto- just in case.

data.title: Add "Never" underline mode to LinkButton
data.body: This trivial patch makes it possible to use LinkButton without any underline at all by adding a third "Never" underline mode.

data.title: Formatting options for integers
data.body:
Lately when handling netcode on Godot, I've been using RawArray to send a customized packet array to my server by `put_data(RawArray)`, and could only do it because the `.to_utf8` converts every char from a string into a byte inside the array. 

So when I was going to write other types of data into the packet array, I noticed that only strings have this formatting feature.

So my proposal is adding features like _int_`.to_32`, that would return a RawArray, just like `.to_utf8` does. It would make the netcode less bound to Godot's packet specification.

data.title: Added update_render_texture function to viewport
data.body:
This patch adds a `update_render_texture` function to the `Viewport` object.

This makes it possible to update a `Viewport`, used to render to a texture, only if it is required.
The Viewports `Update Mode` need to be set to `Never` (only draw after update_render_texture call) or `Once` (draw initially and after that update calls are required.)

In its behavior it is similar to the `queue_screen_capture`function but doesn't generate a image.

data.title: Godot crashes when a certain gdscript file is in the project folder
data.body:
Issue experienced on Windows 7 and Windows 10 - Godot version 2.1

Description: When Godot has a certain gdscript somewhere within "res://", it crashes when this file is either previewed in the file browser, opened, or saved within Godot. This problematic .gd file is attached to this issue. A way to prevent the crash is to mess with lines 30 and 31:

```
var x = 200 * cos(2 * PI / (0))
var y = 200 * sin(2 * PI / (0))
```

If either of these lines are deleted, Godot won't crash. If either of these lines are changed enough, Godot won't crash. It makes no sense to me why the editor seems to crash only in the case that these lines are present in a file.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Download the attached file
2. Change the file extension from .txt to .gd
3. Create a new Godot project
4. Put the downloaded .gd file in the Godot project's root directory
5. Open the project
6. Open the .gd file within Godot
7. Try to save the .gd file a number of times

Godot should crash at some point during this process.

[Game.txt](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/557495/Game.txt)

data.title: Fix locale for macOS-style locales
data.body: Addresses #6942.

data.title: Invalid locale en-CA on MacOS Sierra (conversion needed to en_CA)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
OS: MacOS Sierra 10.12.1
Godot version: latest git
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When running godot engine I noticed I got the error: 

```
ERROR: set_locale: Invalid Locale: en-CA
   At: core/translation.cpp:910.
```

en_CA is a valid locale though. MacOS Sierra (possibly older version I don't know) seems to use a different locale naming scheme that screws the detection up. I also noticed that in issue #6301's log it mentioned that `set_locale: Invalid Locale: en-US` further proving my point.
**Steps to reproduce:**
Build godot engine on MacOS sierra, run it, observe log for Invalid Locale errors.

data.title: Add the ability to delete bezier path handles.
data.body:
This fixes #502. It essentially just adds a few additional checks that try to position-match on a given point's curve controls whenever it's deleting.

This essentially allows you to treat the control points as if they were points in the path, and delete them by either left-clicking while in delete-mode, or right-clicking while in edit-mode.

data.title: fix bug introduced by #6501
data.body:
( @Akien : this PR is for current HEAD only, not to be cherry-picked for 2.1.1 )

this is manual revertion of #6501 which introduced a bug that prevented
scons from detecting Mingw under Windows when MSVC was installed.
(thanks to @vnen for finding this)

AND
it fixes the actual bug that prevented scons from detecting MSVC standalone
compiler ( a confusions between `VSINSTALLDIR` and `VCINSTALLDIR` )

The freeware Standalone MSVC C++ Build Tools are available here :
http://landinghub.visualstudio.com/visual-cpp-build-tools
